question.title: Prime Number Checker iterating and printing every element when only the last element needs to be printed, How can this be solved?
question.body:
I am a beginner programmer currently writing a program that will check if a number is prime or not, and then if a number below zero, print out a couple extra details. Those details would be the maximum and minimum number entered, and all numbers + all prime numbers entered. Right now, I'm currently having a problem where if I enter a number to be checked, the program will print out a large amount of lines, varying between "x is not prime' and 'x is prime.' A shortened source code is below. Any tips and advice is highly appreciated. A picture is also attached of what the console prints. enter image description here

Also - this is my first time asking a question here. I've tried searching around, but didn't find anything.


public class primechecker {
    public static void main(String args[])
    {
        Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
        int x = sc.nextInt();
        while(x>0) {
            for(int i = 2;i<x;i++)
            {
                if(x % i == 0)
                {
                    System.out.println(x + " isn't quite prime.");
                }
                else
                {
                    System.out.println(x + " is so prime.");
                }
                
            }
                x = sc.nextInt();
                if(x < 0)
                {
                    sc.close();
                    break;
                }
            }   
    }
    }

I tried adding a boolean, changing the else is (x % i !== 0), all of which still give me a problem. I didn't try anything you might have thought of though.

answers.body:
You're printing inside the loop, so it prints a line for every check. Instead, use a flag to check if the number is prime, and only print once after the loop.

boolean isPrime = true;
for (int i = 2; i <= x / 2; i++) {
    if (x % i == 0) {
        isPrime = false;
        break;
    }
}
if (isPrime) {
    System.out.println(x + " is so prime.");
} else {
    System.out.println(x + " isn't quite prime.");
}

Put this inside your while (x > 0) loop. This way, it only prints once per input.

The problem lies in the logic itself. To determine that it is not prime, it is enough for it to enter the if once, which indicates that it is divisible by “x.” However, to determine that it is prime, it has to pass all the checks that it is not prime, so your code should look like this:

class primechecker {

   public static void main( String args[] ) {
      Scanner sc = new Scanner( System.in );
      int x = sc.nextInt();
      while( x > 0 ) {
         for( int i = 2; i < x; i ++ ) {

              // It suffices for this condition to be true once to determine
              // that it is not prime, so we add the call to “return.”
            if( x % i == 0 ) {
               System.out.println( x + " isn't quite prime." );
               return;
            }
         }

           // If it never enters the *if* statement, the execution will reach
           // this point, so we print the corresponding message.
         System.out.println( x + " is so prime." );
         x = sc.nextInt();
         if( x < 0 ) {
            sc.close();
            break;
         }
      }
   }
}

Now let's see how to do it “correctly.”

  // We adopted a convention for the names of classes, methods, and variables.
class PrimeChecker {

     // we separate the check from the rest of the code, thus creating a 
     // reusable method that can even be hosted in an auxiliary class,
     // since it does not depend on class attributes
   public boolean isPrime( int candidateNumber ) {
      for( int i = 2; i < candidateNumber; i ++ ) {
         if( candidateNumber % i == 0 ) {               
            return false;
         }
      }
      return true;
   }

     // we removed the code from “main” to avoid declaring “static” methods
     // and variables.
   void init() {
      Scanner sc = new Scanner( System.in );

        // we assign a descriptive name
      int candidateNumber;

        // we declare an infinite loop and perform the check to exit within it.
      while( true ) {
         System.out.println( "Enter an integer to find out if it is prime"
              + ", or a negative number to exit." );
         candidateNumber = sc.nextInt();
         if( candidateNumber == 0 ) {
            sc.close();
            return;
         }
         if( isPrime( candidateNumber )) {
            System.out.println( candidateNumber + " is so prime." );
         }
         else {
            System.out.println( candidateNumber + " isn't quite prime." );
         }
      }
   } 
   
   public static void main( String args[] ) {
      PrimeChecker priChe = new PrimeChecker();
      priChe.init();
   }
}

Note: “correctly” is in parentheses because, for me, if it works, it's correct, but we can make it more readable and reusable this way.

79759231.body: Thank you so much! I was wondering why each loop doing this used a boolean, I could never figure out how to implement it properly.

@user85421 Good point! You are right, checking up to √x is more efficient than x/2, since any larger factor would’ve already been found earlier. And yes, once we've checked for 2, we can skip all even numbers. The 6k ± 1 trick is also a smart way to cut down checks even more. Nice catch!

incomplete optimization! Why not i <= sqrt(x) (or i*i <= x)? - there is no need to test for numbers greater than sqrt(x) (e.g. if already tested if divisible by 2, no need to test for x/2). Also no need to test even numbers after 2 - if a number is not divisible by 2, it will not be by any even number (4, 6, ...) [more optimization: only test for 2, 3, 6*i-1 and 6*i+1]
@user85421 It uses i <= x / 2 because a number can't be divided evenly by anything bigger than half of it (except itself). So we only check up to x / 2.
